content.text:
# Your Job

Scan https://github.com/zeroclaw-labs/zeroclaw, https://github.com/openclaw/openclaw, and https://github.com/stephengpope/thepopebot for new tools, skills, and architectures. Implement AS MANY new ideas as you can as PopeBot skills in your sandbox (.pi/skills/). For EACH skill: create the SKILL.md, write the implementation code, and write and run a test to prove it works. Do not stop at one skill â€” keep going until you run out of good ideas or time. After you have built and tested everything, use the send_email tool to email winsorllc@yahoo.com a comprehensive progress report listing every skill you built, your test results for each, and code samples.

content.thinking:
This is an exciting task! I need to:
1. Scan three GitHub repositories for new tools, skills, and architectures
2. Implement as many new ideas as possible as PopeBot skills in the .pi/skills/ directory
3. For each skill: create SKILL.md, write implementation code, and write/run tests
4. Email a comprehensive progress report to winsorllc@yahoo.com

Let me start by exploring the three repositories to understand what's available. I'll use the http-request skill to fetch repository information and then look at their structures.

Let me begin by exploring these repositories systematically. I'll start with thepopebot since that's the core system I'm working with, then look at zeroclaw and openclaw.

content.thinking: Good, I have the basic repo info. Now let me explore the directory structures and look for skills, tools, and interesting architectures in each repo. Let me start by looking at the contents of each repository.

Let me explore the skills directories and interesting architecture patterns from these repos. I'll look at:
1. zeroclaw-labs/zeroclaw - Rust-based, look at crates/ and skills
2. openclaw/openclaw - TypeScript monorepo, has skills/ folder
3. stephengpope/thepopebot - The base package, look at lib/ for existing patterns

content.thinking:
Great! I found a lot of interesting skills in openclaw/openclaw. Let me explore some of these skills to understand their structure and implementation, then create similar PopeBot skills. Let me look at a few promising ones:

1. blogwatcher - RSS/blog monitoring
2. discord - Discord integration
3. github - GitHub operations
4. notion - Notion integration
5. slack - Slack integration
6. tmux - Terminal multiplexer control
7. trello - Trello operations
8. weather - Weather API
9. openai-image-gen - Image generation
10. openai-whisper - Speech transcription

Let me explore the structure of these skills to understand how they work.
